answers.answer: It is completely not normal to black out under any circumstance.  That said, could be a fairly common diagnosis for you, everything from anemia to diabetes to epilepsy.  But there are many reasons why this could be happening, so you've got to visit a neurologist to sift through the evidence, and because you do not ever want to black out again.  So, set up an appointment with a neuro right away.  In the meantime, see your regular doc and get some blood drawn to check for anemia, vitamin and mineral deficiencies, electrolytes, and he can do a few other tests/exams to rule out anything simple.  And you, you take it easy, don't be driving anywhere for the duration of seeing the specialist.  Be sure you eat well, drink plenty of fluids, and keep up with mild activity.

Hi,Low blood sugar, dehydration, low or high BP can cause headaches with black outs. However these could also be symptoms of a neurological condition also. I would suggest you to make sure you do not skip your meals eat on time and drink plenty of water and increase your salt intake.If the symptoms still persist please get a clinical evaluation done.Good luck!

question: what causes headaches and blackouts?i keep getting headaches that last a few weeks and take for ever to get rid of, almost every time i get a headache i end up blacking out and don't know why. it startes with a headache, then i have trouble seeing, and hearing, then i get dizzy and blackout. if i sit down when my vision starts to go it goes away but if i get up too fast it comes back.
title: headsches, and blackouts
